Legal_Issue: Did the officer correctly assess the applicant's education credentials under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations?
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant provided a medical degree and specialty diploma; no evidence supported equivalency to a PhD
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate error in assessment
Credibility_Factor: Lack of supporting documentation for PhD claim
Legal_Rule: Under subsection 78(2), master’s or doctoral degree earns 25 points; two bachelor’s degrees earn 22 points
Procedural_Issue: Assessment of educational credentials and procedural fairness
Grounds_for_Claim: Dispute over educational credential assessment leading to insufficient points for permanent residency
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to officer's interpretation
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical degree, specialty diploma, lack of PhD verification
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged denial of points for PhD credential
Legal_Rule_Source: Subsection 78(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Defendant_Response: Officer awarded 22 points based on available credentials
Legal_Provision: Subsection 78(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Insufficient points due to credential assessment
Applicable_Process: Express Entry or economic class application process
Governing_Rule: Subsection 78(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
